trans-unit.source: How to debug a Node.js web app in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: How to debug a Node.js web app in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: Learn how to debug a Node.js web app in Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to debug a Node.js web app in Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: How to debug a Node.js web app in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: How to debug a Node.js web app in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: Azure provides built-in diagnostics to assist with debugging Node.js applications hosted in [Azure App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=529714) Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: Azure provides built-in diagnostics to assist with debugging Node.js applications hosted in [Azure App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=529714) Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: In this article, you will learn how to enable logging of stdout and stderr, display error information in the browser, and how to download and view log files.
trans-unit.target: In this article, you will learn how to enable logging of stdout and stderr, display error information in the browser, and how to download and view log files.

trans-unit.source: Diagnostics for Node.js applications hosted on Azure is provided by [IISNode].
trans-unit.target: Diagnostics for Node.js applications hosted on Azure is provided by [IISNode].

trans-unit.source: While this article discusses the most common settings for gathering diagnostics information, it does not provide a complete reference for working with IISNode.
trans-unit.target: While this article discusses the most common settings for gathering diagnostics information, it does not provide a complete reference for working with IISNode.

trans-unit.source: For more information on working with IISNode, see the [IISNode Readme] on GitHub.
trans-unit.target: For more information on working with IISNode, see the [IISNode Readme] on GitHub.

trans-unit.source: Enable logging
trans-unit.target: Enable logging

trans-unit.source: By default, an App Service web app only captures diagnostic information about deployments, such as when you deploy a web app using Git.
trans-unit.target: By default, an App Service web app only captures diagnostic information about deployments, such as when you deploy a web app using Git.

trans-unit.source: This information is useful if you are having problems during deployment, such as a failure when installing a module referenced in **package.json**, or if you are using a custom deployment script.
trans-unit.target: This information is useful if you are having problems during deployment, such as a failure when installing a module referenced in **package.json**, or if you are using a custom deployment script.

trans-unit.source: To enable the logging of stdout and stderr streams, you must create an **IISNode.yml** file at the root of your Node.js application and add the following:
trans-unit.target: To enable the logging of stdout and stderr streams, you must create an **IISNode.yml** file at the root of your Node.js application and add the following:

trans-unit.source: This enables the logging of stderr and stdout from your Node.js application.
trans-unit.target: This enables the logging of stderr and stdout from your Node.js application.

trans-unit.source: The **IISNode.yml** file can also be used to control whether friendly errors or developer errors are returned to the browser when a failure occurs.
trans-unit.target: The **IISNode.yml** file can also be used to control whether friendly errors or developer errors are returned to the browser when a failure occurs.

trans-unit.source: To enable developer errors, add the following line to the **IISNode.yml** file:
trans-unit.target: To enable developer errors, add the following line to the **IISNode.yml** file:

trans-unit.source: Once this option is enabled, IISNode will return the last 64K of information sent to stderr instead of a friendly error such as "an internal server error occurred".
trans-unit.target: Once this option is enabled, IISNode will return the last 64K of information sent to stderr instead of a friendly error such as "an internal server error occurred".

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] While devErrorsEnabled is useful when diagnosing problems during development, enabling it in a production environment may result in development errors being sent to end users.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] While devErrorsEnabled is useful when diagnosing problems during development, enabling it in a production environment may result in development errors being sent to end users.

trans-unit.source: If the **IISNode.yml** file did not already exist within your application, you must restart your web app after publishing the updated application.
trans-unit.target: If the **IISNode.yml** file did not already exist within your application, you must restart your web app after publishing the updated application.

trans-unit.source: If you are simply changing settings in an existing **IISNode.yml** file that has previously been published, no restart is required.
trans-unit.target: If you are simply changing settings in an existing **IISNode.yml** file that has previously been published, no restart is required.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If your web app was created using the Azure Command-Line Tools or Azure PowerShell Cmdlets, a default **IISNode.yml** file is automatically created.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If your web app was created using the Azure Command-Line Tools or Azure PowerShell Cmdlets, a default **IISNode.yml** file is automatically created.

trans-unit.source: To restart the web app, select the web app in the [Azure preview portal](https://portal.azure.com), and then click **RESTART** button:
trans-unit.target: To restart the web app, select the web app in the [Azure preview portal](https://portal.azure.com), and then click **RESTART** button:

trans-unit.source: restart button
trans-unit.target: restart button

trans-unit.source: If the Azure Command-Line Tools are installed in your development environment, you can use the following command to restart the web app:
trans-unit.target: If the Azure Command-Line Tools are installed in your development environment, you can use the following command to restart the web app:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] While loggingEnabled and devErrorsEnabled are the most commonly used IISNode.yml configuration options for capturing diagnostic information, IISNode.yml can be used to configure a variety of options for your hosting environment.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] While loggingEnabled and devErrorsEnabled are the most commonly used IISNode.yml configuration options for capturing diagnostic information, IISNode.yml can be used to configure a variety of options for your hosting environment.

trans-unit.source: For a full list of the configuration options, see the [iisnode_schema.xml](https://github.com/tjanczuk/iisnode/blob/master/src/config/iisnode_schema.xml) file.
trans-unit.target: For a full list of the configuration options, see the [iisnode_schema.xml](https://github.com/tjanczuk/iisnode/blob/master/src/config/iisnode_schema.xml) file.

trans-unit.source: Accessing logs
trans-unit.target: Accessing logs

trans-unit.source: Diagnostic logs can be accessed in three ways; Using the File Transfer Protocol (FTP), downloading a Zip archive, or as a live updated stream of the log (also known as a tail).
trans-unit.target: Diagnostic logs can be accessed in three ways; Using the File Transfer Protocol (FTP), downloading a Zip archive, or as a live updated stream of the log (also known as a tail).

trans-unit.source: Downloading the Zip archive of the log files or viewing the live stream require the Azure Command-Line Tools.
trans-unit.target: Downloading the Zip archive of the log files or viewing the live stream require the Azure Command-Line Tools.

trans-unit.source: These can be installed by using the following command:
trans-unit.target: These can be installed by using the following command:

trans-unit.source: Once installed, the tools can be accessed using the 'azure' command.
trans-unit.target: Once installed, the tools can be accessed using the 'azure' command.

trans-unit.source: The command-line tools must first be configured to use your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: The command-line tools must first be configured to use your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: For information on how to accomplish this task, see the **How to download and import publish settings** section of the [How to Use The Azure Command-Line Tools] article.
trans-unit.target: For information on how to accomplish this task, see the **How to download and import publish settings** section of the [How to Use The Azure Command-Line Tools] article.

trans-unit.source: FTP
trans-unit.target: FTP

trans-unit.source: To access the diagnostic information through FTP, visit the [Azure preview portal](https://portal.azure.com), select your web app, and then select the **DASHBOARD**.
trans-unit.target: To access the diagnostic information through FTP, visit the [Azure preview portal](https://portal.azure.com), select your web app, and then select the **DASHBOARD**.

trans-unit.source: In the **quick links** section, the **FTP DIAGNOSTIC LOGS** and **FTPS DIAGNOSTIC LOGS** links provide access to the logs using the FTP protocol.
trans-unit.target: In the **quick links** section, the **FTP DIAGNOSTIC LOGS** and **FTPS DIAGNOSTIC LOGS** links provide access to the logs using the FTP protocol.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you have not previously configured user name and password for FTP or deployment, you can do so from the **QuickStart** management page by selecting **Set up deployment credentials**.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you have not previously configured user name and password for FTP or deployment, you can do so from the **QuickStart** management page by selecting **Set up deployment credentials**.

trans-unit.source: The FTP URL returned in the dashboard is for the **LogFiles** directory, which will contain the following sub-directories:
trans-unit.target: The FTP URL returned in the dashboard is for the **LogFiles** directory, which will contain the following sub-directories:

trans-unit.source: [Deployment Method] - If you use a deployment method such as Git, a directory of the same name will be created and will contain information related to deployments.
trans-unit.target: [Deployment Method] - If you use a deployment method such as Git, a directory of the same name will be created and will contain information related to deployments.

trans-unit.source: nodejs - Stdout and stderr information captured from all instances of your application (when loggingEnabled is true.)
trans-unit.target: nodejs - Stdout and stderr information captured from all instances of your application (when loggingEnabled is true.)

trans-unit.source: Zip archive
trans-unit.target: Zip archive

trans-unit.source: To download a Zip archive of the diagnostic logs, use the following command from the Azure Command-Line Tools:
trans-unit.target: To download a Zip archive of the diagnostic logs, use the following command from the Azure Command-Line Tools:

trans-unit.source: This will download a **diagnostics.zip** in the current directory.
trans-unit.target: This will download a **diagnostics.zip** in the current directory.

trans-unit.source: This archive contains the following directory structure:
trans-unit.target: This archive contains the following directory structure:

trans-unit.source: deployments - A log of information about deployments of your application
trans-unit.target: deployments - A log of information about deployments of your application

trans-unit.source: LogFiles
trans-unit.target: LogFiles

trans-unit.source: [Deployment method] - If you use a deployment method such as Git, a directory of the same name will be created and will contain information related to deployments.
trans-unit.target: [Deployment method] - If you use a deployment method such as Git, a directory of the same name will be created and will contain information related to deployments.

trans-unit.source: nodejs - Stdout and stderr information captured from all instances of your application (when loggingEnabled is true.)
trans-unit.target: nodejs - Stdout and stderr information captured from all instances of your application (when loggingEnabled is true.)

trans-unit.source: Live stream (tail)
trans-unit.target: Live stream (tail)

trans-unit.source: To view a live stream of diagnostic log information, use the following command from the Azure Command-Line Tools:
trans-unit.target: To view a live stream of diagnostic log information, use the following command from the Azure Command-Line Tools:

trans-unit.source: This will return a stream of log events that are updated as they occur on the server.
trans-unit.target: This will return a stream of log events that are updated as they occur on the server.

trans-unit.source: This stream will return deployment information as well as stdout and stderr information (when loggingEnabled is true.)
trans-unit.target: This stream will return deployment information as well as stdout and stderr information (when loggingEnabled is true.)

trans-unit.source: Next Steps
trans-unit.target: Next Steps

trans-unit.source: In this article you learned how to enable and access diagnostics information for Azure.
trans-unit.target: In this article you learned how to enable and access diagnostics information for Azure.

trans-unit.source: While this information is useful in understanding problems that occur with your application, it may point to a problem with a module you are using or that the version of Node.js used by App Service Web Apps is different than the one used in your deployment environment.
trans-unit.target: While this information is useful in understanding problems that occur with your application, it may point to a problem with a module you are using or that the version of Node.js used by App Service Web Apps is different than the one used in your deployment environment.

trans-unit.source: For information in working with modules on Azure, see [Using Node.js Modules with Azure Applications].
trans-unit.target: For information in working with modules on Azure, see [Using Node.js Modules with Azure Applications].

trans-unit.source: For information on specifying a Node.js version for your application, see [Specifying a Node.js version in an Azure application].
trans-unit.target: For information on specifying a Node.js version for your application, see [Specifying a Node.js version in an Azure application].

trans-unit.source: What's changed
trans-unit.target: What's changed

trans-unit.source: For a guide to the change from Websites to App Service see: [Azure App Service and Its Impact on Existing Azure Services](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=529714)
trans-unit.target: For a guide to the change from Websites to App Service see: [Azure App Service and Its Impact on Existing Azure Services](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=529714)

trans-unit.source: For a guide to the change of the old portal to the new portal see: [Reference for navigating the preview portal](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=529715)
trans-unit.target: For a guide to the change of the old portal to the new portal see: [Reference for navigating the preview portal](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=529715)

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to [Try App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=523751), where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to [Try App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=523751), where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: No credit cards required; no commitments.
trans-unit.target: No credit cards required; no commitments.
